review.title: An evaluation of keyword extraction from online communication for the characterisation of social relations
review.abstract: The set of interpersonal relationships on a social network service or a similar online community is usually highly heterogenous. The concept of tie strength captures only one aspect of this heterogeneity. Since the unstructured text content of online communication artefacts is a salient source of information about a social relationship, we investigate the utility of keywords extracted from the message body as a representation of the relationship's characteristics as reflected by the conversation topics. Keyword extraction is performed using standard natural language processing methods. Communication data and human assessments of the extracted keywords are obtained from Facebook users via a custom application. The overall positive quality assessment provides evidence that the keywords indeed convey relevant information about the relationship.

sections.heading: 1.2 Research Questions
sections.text: Starting with the problem, we formulate two research questions: 1. Is it possible to extract a set of keywords from communication artifacts that a human observer considers to be a good representation of the associated social relationship? The intuition is that if sufficient data is gathered from the background noise of words with a predominantly conversation-specific function, a pattern of keywords will emerge. 2. Will a representation considered correct by a human observer inversely improve the performance of social computing systems? In this work, we will focus on the first question and evaluate a keyword extraction system for text messages exchanged between users of the social network Facebook. Section 2.1 describes the design of the keyword extraction system in detail. In Section 2.2, we will build a Facebook application that analyzes private messages and receives user feedback on the quality of the extracted keywords. The results will be presented in Section 3.

sections.heading: 2 Experimental Setting
sections.text: In order to obtain a representative sample of interpersonal communication, a large amount of messages needs to be collected. We chose Facebook as the data source because it is known for its large user base and network effects ("viral marketing"). Facebook enables users to declare "friendship" with each other and exchange private messages. The "friend" relationship across users corresponds to individual social relationships that may differ in emotional and geographic proximity. For example, Facebook is often used as the primary tool for maintaining relationships between geographically distant people (Bryant and Marmo, 2009). Facebook offers an API that allows third-party developers to integrate their applications into the user interface and access user profile data as far as possible through the privacy of an individual user. The Facebook application developed for this study fulfills three distinct tasks: private messages sent and received by a user are collected via the API, from the messages collected, each key word is asked for each sender pair, and finally, a set of sender words is extracted by the user.

sections.heading: 3 Results
sections.text: The data was collected over a period of approximately 2.5 months. During this period, 98 Facebook users installed the application, and 71 users actually submitted usable data. Ratings were submitted for 275 relationships. 46 users (65%) removed an average of one or more words from a keyword sentence before submitting their rating. The average number of messages associated with a relationship is 20, with an average number of 36 words per message. There is a strong linear correlation between the amount of messages sent and received per relationship, with Peer's correlation coefficient of 0.92 for the relationship of messages and ρ = 0.9 for the ratio of total word count. sections.heading: 4 Related Work
sections.text: Culotta et al. (2004) build a system for extracting social networks from the web that acts like a web crawler, extracting keywords from discovered personal web pages for the specified purpose of expert identification; the quality of the keywords is not evaluated beyond a basic visual inspection; Mori et al.
